continent.name: Anger
continent.desc: We get angry when something blocks us or when we think we're being treated unfairly.
continent.desc_mobile: We feel anger when we are mentally or physically blocked. Anger varies in strength and frequency in our lives.

states.name: Annoyance
states.desc: Very mild anger caused by a nuisance or inconvenience.
states.desc_mobile: Very mild anger caused by a nuisance or inconvenience.
states.secondary: Anger contains both annoyance and fury. The intensity of these states varies: We can feel mild or strong annoyance, but we can only feel intense fury. All states of anger are triggered by a feeling of being blocked in our progress.

states.name: Frustration
states.desc: A response to repeated failures to overcome an obstacle.
states.desc_mobile: A response to repeated failures to overcome an obstacle.

states.name: Argumentativeness
states.desc: A tendency to engage in disagreements.
states.desc_mobile: A tendency to engage in disagreements.

states.name: Bitterness
states.desc: Anger after unfair treatment.
states.desc_mobile: Anger after unfair treatment.

states.name: Exasperation
states.desc: Anger caused by a repeated or strong nuisance.
states.desc_mobile: Anger caused by a repeated or strong nuisance.

states.name: Vengefulness
states.desc: Desire to retaliate after one is hurt.
states.desc_mobile: Desire to retaliate after one is hurt.

states.name: Fury
states.desc: Uncontrolled and often violent anger.
states.desc_mobile: Uncontrolled and often violent anger.

actions.name: Quarrel
actions.desc: Verbally oppose in a manner intended to escalate the disagreement.
actions.desc_mobile: Verbally oppose in a manner intended to escalate the disagreement.
actions.secondary: For example, we might suppress our feelings of frustration at work, but scream and yell to express our frustration with a family member. Suppressing our frustration can be constructive in cases where it helps us avoid arguments, but destructive if we are being hurt by not speaking up for ourselves.

actions.name: Insult
actions.desc: Disparage the other person in an offensive or hurtful way that is likely to escalate the conflict rather than resolve it.
actions.desc_mobile: Disparage the other person in an offensive or hurtful way that is likely to escalate the conflict rather than resolve it.

actions.name: Undermine
actions.desc: Take action to make someone or something weaker or less effective, usually in a secret or gradual way.
actions.desc_mobile: Take action to make someone or something weaker or less effective, usually in a secret or gradual way.

actions.name: Dispute
actions.desc: Disagree in a manner that may escalate the conflict.
actions.desc_mobile: Disagree in a manner that may escalate the conflict.

actions.name: Scream/yell
actions.desc: Lose control of one's speech; speak loudly and possibly at a higher pitch.
actions.desc_mobile: Lose control of one's speech; speak loudly and possibly at a higher pitch.

actions.name: Use physical force
actions.desc: Harm or trap someone.
actions.desc_mobile: Harm or trap someone.

actions.name: Suppress
actions.desc: Try to avoid feeling or acting upon the emotion that is being experienced.
actions.desc_mobile: Try to avoid feeling or acting upon the emotion that is being experienced.

actions.name: Simmer/brood
actions.desc: Express anger by sulking.
actions.desc_mobile: Express anger by sulking.

actions.name: Be passive-aggressive
actions.desc: Take indirect actions that have an angry undercurrent.
actions.desc_mobile: Take indirect actions that have an angry undercurrent.

triggers.name: Interference with action
triggers.desc_mobile: Universal triggers are innate, common to everyone, and affect us more intensely than learned triggers. Interference with action or locomotion are examples.

triggers.name: Rejection by a loved one
triggers.desc_mobile: Some triggers can be learned from personal or shared cultural experiences. Being wrongfully accused or put down by an authority figure are examples.

triggers.name: Being put down by an authority figure
triggers.name_mobile: Being put down by an authority figure

moods.name: Irritable
moods.desc: Predisposed to becoming angry, easily provoked.
moods.desc_mobile: Predisposed to becoming angry, easily provoked.

trigger.event: a friend gets upset with you

continent.name: Fear
continent.desc: Our fear of danger lets us anticipate threats to our safety.
continent.desc_mobile: We feel fear when our safety or wellbeing is threatened. Fear varies in strength and frequency in our lives.

states.name: Trepidation
states.desc: Anticipation of the possibility of danger.
states.desc_mobile: Anticipation of the possibility of danger.
states.secondary: Fear contains both anxiety and terror. The intensity of these states varies: We can feel mild or strong anxiety, but we can only feel intense terror. All states of fear are triggered by feeling a threat of harm.

states.name: Anxiety
states.desc: Fear of an anticipated or actual threat and uncertainty about one's ability to cope with it.
states.desc_mobile: Fear of an anticipated or actual threat and uncertainty about one's ability to cope with it.

states.name: Nervousness
states.desc: Uncertainty as to whether there is a danger.
states.desc_mobile: Uncertainty as to whether there is a danger.

states.name: Dread
states.desc: Anticipation of severe danger.
states.desc_mobile: Anticipation of severe danger.

states.name: Desperation
states.desc: A response to the inability to reduce danger.
states.desc_mobile: A response to the inability to reduce danger.

states.name: Panic
states.desc: Sudden uncontrollable fear.
states.desc_mobile: Sudden uncontrollable fear.

states.name: Horror
states.desc: A mixture of fear, disgust, and shock.
states.desc_mobile: A mixture of fear, disgust, and shock.

states.name: Terror
states.desc: Intense, overpowering fear.
states.desc_mobile: Intense, overpowering fear.

actions.name: Withdraw
actions.desc: Physically or mentally leave the scene of the threat.
actions.desc_mobile: Physically or mentally leave the scene of the threat.
actions.secondary: For example, we might avoid feeling anxiety at work, but ruminate on our anxiety at home. Avoiding anxiety can be constructive if it helps us give a presentation to a room full of colleagues, but destructive if it prevents us from confronting our difficult relationship with our boss.

actions.name: Avoid
actions.desc: Either physically stay away from the threat or keep oneself from thinking about it.
actions.desc_mobile: Either physically stay away from the threat or keep oneself from thinking about it.

actions.name: Hesitate
actions.desc: Hold back in doubt or indecision, often momentarily.
actions.desc_mobile: Hold back in doubt or indecision, often momentarily.

actions.name: Freeze
actions.desc: Become incapable of acting or speaking.
actions.desc_mobile: Become incapable of acting or speaking.

actions.name: Scream/yell
actions.desc: Lose control of one's speech; cry out in a loud and high voice.
actions.desc_mobile: Lose control of one's speech; cry out in a loud and high voice.

actions.name: Ruminate
actions.desc: Obsessively think about a past emotional experience.
actions.desc_mobile: Obsessively think about a past emotional experience.

actions.name: Worry
actions.desc: Anticipate the possibility of harm.
actions.desc_mobile: Anticipate the possibility of harm.

triggers.name: Imminent bodily impact
triggers.desc_mobile: Universal triggers are innate, common to everyone, and affect us more intensely than learned triggers. Snake-like shapes and sudden loss of gravity are examples.

triggers.name: Sudden loss of gravity
triggers.desc_mobile: Some triggers can be learned from personal or shared cultural experiences. Public speaking, thunder, and the threat of losing one's job are examples.

moods.name: Apprehensive
moods.desc: Anxious that something bad will happen, on edge.
moods.desc_mobile: Anxious that something bad will happen, on edge.

trigger.event: a friend gets angry with you

continent.name: Disgust
continent.desc: Feeling disgusted by what is toxic helps us to avoid being poisoned, physically or socially.
continent.desc_mobile: We feel disgust when faced with something toxic or unpleasant. Disgust varies in strength and frequency in our lives.

states.name: Dislike
states.desc: A preference against something.
states.desc_mobile: A preference against something.
states.secondary: Disgust contains both dislike and loathing. The intensity of these states varies: We can feel mild or strong dislike, but we can only feel intense loathing. All states of disgust are triggered by the feeling that something is toxic.

states.name: Aversion
states.desc: An impulse to avoid something disgusting.
states.desc_mobile: An impulse to avoid something disgusting.

states.name: Distaste
states.desc: Reaction to a bad taste, smell, thing or idea. Can be literal or metaphorical.
states.desc_mobile: Reaction to a bad taste, smell, thing or idea. Can be literal or metaphorical.

states.name: Repugnance
states.desc: Strong distaste for something, often a concept or idea.
states.desc_mobile: Strong distaste for something, often a concept or idea.

states.name: Revulsion
states.desc: A mixture of disgust and loathing.
states.desc_mobile: A mixture of disgust and loathing.

states.name: Abhorrence
states.desc: A mixture of intense disgust and hatred.
states.desc_mobile: A mixture of intense disgust and hatred.

states.name: Loathing
states.desc: Intense disgust focused on a person. Intense disgust focused on oneself is called self-loathing.
states.desc_mobile: Intense disgust focused on a person. Intense disgust focused on oneself is called self-loathing.

actions.name: Withdraw
actions.desc: Physically or mentally leave the scene of what is triggering the disgust.
actions.desc_mobile: Physically or mentally leave the scene of what is triggering the disgust.
actions.secondary: For example, we might avoid feeling aversion towards others at work, but find ourselves feeling aversion towards individuals we read about in the news. Avoiding aversion can be constructive in overcoming bias, but can be destructive if it leads us to get involved with a harmful person.

actions.name: Avoid
actions.desc: Either physically stay away from whatever is triggering the disgust or keep oneself from thinking about it.
actions.desc_mobile: Either physically stay away from whatever is triggering the disgust or keep oneself from thinking about it.

actions.name: Vomit
actions.desc: Respond to feelings of disgust by throwing up.
actions.desc_mobile: Respond to feelings of disgust by throwing up.

actions.name: Dehumanize
actions.desc: Treat someone as though he or she is not a human being; deprive someone of human qualities, personality or spirit.
actions.desc_mobile: Treat someone as though he or she is not a human being; deprive someone of human qualities, personality or spirit.

triggers.name: Anything coming out of the body
triggers.desc_mobile: Universal triggers are innate, common to everyone, and affect us more intensely than learned triggers. Anything in decay or coming out of the body are examples.

triggers.name: Rotting or decay
triggers.desc_mobile: Some triggers can be learned from personal or shared cultural experiences. Unfamiliar religious customs and eating insects or raw meat are examples.

triggers.name: Fans of an opposing sports team
triggers.name_mobile: Fans of an opposing sports team

trigger.precondition: you are having a hard day
trigger.event: a friend gets angry with you

continent.name: Sadness
continent.desc: Sadness is a response to loss, and feeling sad allows us to take a timeout and show others that we need support.
continent.desc_mobile: We feel sadness when we lose something valuable. Sadness varies in strength and frequency in our lives.

states.name: Disappointment
states.desc: A feeling that expectations are not being met.
states.desc_mobile: A feeling that expectations are not being met.
states.secondary: Sadness contains both disappointment and despair. The intensity of these states varies: We can feel mild or strong disappointment, but we can only feel intense despair. All states of sadness are triggered by a feeling of loss.

states.name: Resignation
states.desc: The belief that nothing can be done.
states.desc_mobile: The belief that nothing can be done.

states.name: Distraughtness
states.desc: Sadness that makes it hard to think clearly.
states.desc_mobile: Sadness that makes it hard to think clearly.

states.name: Discouragement
states.desc: A response to repeated failures to accomplish something: the belief that it can't be done.
states.desc_mobile: A response to repeated failures to accomplish something: the belief that it can't be done.

states.name: Helplessness
states.desc: The realization that one cannot make a situation better or easier.
states.desc_mobile: The realization that one cannot make a situation better or easier.

states.name: Misery
states.desc: Strong suffering or unhappiness.
states.desc_mobile: Strong suffering or unhappiness.

states.name: Hopelessness
states.desc: The belief that nothing good will happen.
states.desc_mobile: The belief that nothing good will happen.

states.name: Grief
states.desc: Sadness over a deep loss.
states.desc_mobile: Sadness over a deep loss.

states.name: Despair
states.desc: The loss of hope that a bad situation will improve or change.
states.desc_mobile: The loss of hope that a bad situation will improve or change.

states.name: Sorrow
states.desc: A feeling of distress and sadness, often caused by a loss.
states.desc_mobile: A feeling of distress and sadness, often caused by a loss.

states.name: Anguish
states.desc: Intense sadness or suffering.
states.desc_mobile: Intense sadness or suffering.

actions.name: Seek comfort
actions.desc: Seek help or support from others.
actions.desc_mobile: Seek help or support from others.
actions.secondary: For example, we might withdraw from feeling helpless in public, but seek comfort at home. Withdrawing from feeling helpless can be constructive to overcoming intense grief, but destructive if we don't seek support when we need it.

actions.name: Withdraw
actions.desc: Either physically stay away from what is triggering the sadness or keep oneself from thinking about it.
actions.desc_mobile: Either physically stay away from what is triggering the sadness or keep oneself from thinking about it.

actions.name: Ruminate
actions.desc: Obsessively think about the emotional experience.
actions.desc_mobile: Obsessively think about the emotional experience.

actions.name: Mourn
actions.desc: Express grief for one's loss through actions, dress and speech.
actions.desc_mobile: Express grief for one's loss through actions, dress and speech.

actions.name: Protest
actions.desc: Object to the loss.
actions.desc_mobile: Object to the loss.

actions.name: Feel ashamed
actions.desc: Feel embarrassed by one's feelings about the loss.
actions.desc_mobile: Feel embarrassed by one's feelings about the loss.

triggers.name: Being rejected by someone important
triggers.desc_mobile: Universal triggers are innate, common to everyone, and affect us more intensely than learned triggers. Losing or being rejected by a loved one are examples.

triggers.name: Losing a loved one
triggers.desc_mobile: Some triggers can be learned from personal or shared cultural experiences. Feeling left out or experiencing a perceived loss of status are examples.

triggers.name: Not being invited to a party
triggers.name_mobile: Not being invited to a party

moods.name: Dysphoric (or feeling blue)
moods.desc: An enduring feeling of discouragement or disappointment.
moods.desc_mobile: An enduring feeling of discouragement or disappointment.

trigger.event: a friend gets angry with you

continent.name: Enjoyment
continent.desc: Enjoyment describes the many good feelings that arise from experiences both novel and familiar.
continent.desc_mobile: We feel enjoyment when we experience novelty or comfort. Enjoyment varies in strength and frequency in our lives.

states.name: Sensory pleasure
states.desc: Enjoyment derived through one of the five physical senses: sight, sound, touch, taste and smell.
states.desc_mobile: Enjoyment derived through one of the five physical senses: sight, sound, touch, taste and smell.
states.secondary: Enjoyment contains both peace and ecstasy. The intensity of these states varies: We can feel mild or strong peacefulness, but we can only feel intense ecstasy. All states of enjoyment are triggered by feeling connection and/or sensory pleasure.

states.name: Rejoicing
states.desc: A warm, uplifting feeling that people experience when they see acts of human goodness, kindness and compassion. Also called elevation.
states.desc_mobile: A warm, uplifting feeling that people experience when they see acts of human goodness, kindness and compassion. Also called elevation.

states.name: Amusement
states.desc: Light, playful feelings of enjoyment and good humor.
states.desc_mobile: Light, playful feelings of enjoyment and good humor.

states.name: Relief
states.desc: When something expected to be unpleasant, especially the threat of harm, is avoided or comes to an end.
states.desc_mobile: When something expected to be unpleasant, especially the threat of harm, is avoided or comes to an end.

states.name: Compassion/joy
states.desc: Enjoyment of helping to relieve another person's suffering.
states.desc_mobile: Enjoyment of helping to relieve another person's suffering.

states.name: Schadenfreude
states.desc: Enjoyment of the misfortunes of another person, usually a rival.
states.desc_mobile: Enjoyment of the misfortunes of another person, usually a rival.

states.name: Fiero
states.desc: Enjoyment of meeting a difficult challenge (an Italian word).
states.desc_mobile: Enjoyment of meeting a difficult challenge (an Italian word).

states.name: Naches
states.desc: Joyful pride in the accomplishments of one's children or mentees (a Yiddish word).
states.desc_mobile: Joyful pride in the accomplishments of one's children or mentees (a Yiddish word).

states.name: Pride
states.desc: Deep pleasure and satisfaction derived from one's own achievements or the achievements of an associate.
states.desc_mobile: Deep pleasure and satisfaction derived from one's own achievements or the achievements of an associate.

states.name: Wonder
states.desc: An experience of something that is very surprising, beautiful, amazing or hard to believe.
states.desc_mobile: An experience of something that is very surprising, beautiful, amazing or hard to believe.

states.name: Peace
states.desc: An experience of ease and contentment.
states.desc_mobile: An experience of ease and contentment.

states.name: Excitement
states.desc: A powerful enthusiasm.
states.desc_mobile: A powerful enthusiasm.

states.name: Ecstasy
states.desc: Rapturous delight. A state of very great happiness, nearly overwhelming.
states.desc_mobile: Rapturous delight. A state of very great happiness, nearly overwhelming.

actions.name: Seek more
actions.desc: Attempt to increase the enjoyable feelings.
actions.desc_mobile: Attempt to increase the enjoyable feelings.
actions.secondary: For example, we might exclaim to express our feeling of amusement among friends, but experience our amusement quietly while alone. Expressing amusement by exclaiming can be constructive as means of sharing enjoyment, but destructive if it's in response to making fun of someone.

actions.name: Maintain
actions.desc: Continue to do what is necessary to continue the enjoyable feelings.
actions.desc_mobile: Continue to do what is necessary to continue the enjoyable feelings.

actions.name: Gloat
actions.desc: Enjoy others' envy of your state of enjoyment.
actions.desc_mobile: Enjoy others' envy of your state of enjoyment.

actions.name: Exclaim
actions.desc: Vocally express enjoyment to others.
actions.desc_mobile: Vocally express enjoyment to others.

actions.name: Engage/connect
actions.desc: Share one's feelings of enjoyment with others without a desire to cause jealousy.
actions.desc_mobile: Share one's feelings of enjoyment with others without a desire to cause jealousy.

actions.name: Savor
actions.desc: Appreciate the good feelings around an experience completely, especially by dwelling on them.
actions.desc_mobile: Appreciate the good feelings around an experience completely, especially by dwelling on them.

actions.name: Indulge
actions.desc: Allow oneself to fully experience the pleasure of good feelings.
actions.desc_mobile: Allow oneself to fully experience the pleasure of good feelings.

triggers.name: Sensory experience of nature
triggers.desc_mobile: Universal triggers are innate, common to everyone, and affect us more intensely than learned triggers. Social interaction and experiencing nature are examples.

triggers.name: Helping others
triggers.desc_mobile: Some triggers can be learned from personal or shared cultural experiences. Spending time with family or visiting places from one's youth are examples.

trigger.event: a friend gets angry with you

intro.header: Welcome to the Atlas of Emotions
intro.header_mobile: Welcome to the Atlas of Emotions
intro.body_mobile: This Atlas was inspired by a series of conversations about the science of emotion between the Dalai Lama and Dr. Paul Ekman. Created in collaboration with Stamen Design and Paul's daughter, Dr. Eve Ekman, the Atlas of Emotions is an interactive visual journey through the world of emotions.

steps.header: Welcome to the Atlas of Emotions
steps.body: The first step to managing your emotions is learning to identify and describe what you are feeling.
steps.header_mobile: Welcome to the Atlas of Emotions
steps.body_mobile: The first step to managing your emotions is learning to identify and describe what you are feeling.
steps.caption: This Atlas is a visual tool to build your emotion vocabulary. The goal is to increase choice in what we become emotional about and how we respond.

steps.body:
There are 5 emotions to explore. Discover more about each emotion as you interact with the shapes. Navigate by clicking down, left and right.

Consider each emotion and reflect on how it relates to your lived experience.
steps.body_mobile:
There are 5 emotions to explore. Discover more about each emotion as you interact with the shapes. Navigate by clicking down, left and right.

Consider each emotion and reflect on how it relates to your lived experience.

steps.header: The atlas: a new kind of map
steps.body:
The Atlas was commissioned by the Dalai Lama to create a scientifically-based road map to emotional self-awareness. Dr. Paul Ekman and his daughter, Eve Ekman, based the Atlas on a study they conducted.

The scientists surveyed in the study agreed that these five emotions are the most universally felt:
steps.header_mobile: The atlas: a new kind of map
steps.body_mobile:
The Atlas was commissioned by the Dalai Lama to create a scientifically-based road map to emotional self-awareness. Dr. Paul Ekman and his daughter, Eve Ekman, based the Atlas on a study they conducted.

The scientists surveyed in the study agreed that these five emotions are the most universally felt:
steps.caption: Pick any emotion and start exploring.

hero.header: Welcome to the Atlas of Emotions
hero.header_mobile: Welcome to the Atlas of Emotions

about.body: The Dalai Lama imagined "a map of our emotions to develop a calm mind." He asked his longtime friend and renowned emotion scientist Dr. Paul Ekman to realize his idea. Ekman took on the creation of the Atlas alongside his daughter, Eve Ekman, a second-generation emotion researcher and teacher. The Dalai Lama requested the Atlas represent the science of Emotions from what researchers have learned from the psychological study of emotion.
about.body_mobile: The Dalai Lama imagined "a map of our emotions to develop a calm mind." He asked his longtime friend and renowned emotion scientist Dr. Paul Ekman to realize his idea. Ekman took on the creation of the Atlas alongside his daughter, Eve Ekman, a second-generation emotion researcher and teacher. The Dalai Lama requested the Atlas represent the science of Emotions from what researchers have learned from the psychological study of emotion.

slides: The Atlas is an interactive tool that builds your vocabulary of emotions and illuminates your emotional world.
The goal is to gain greater control over what triggers your emotions and how you respond.
The first step towards emotional awareness is learning to identify and describe how you are feeling, and why.

continents.body: Most emotions researchers agree on these five Universal Emotions: emotions that all humans, no matter where or how we were raised, have in common. The movement of the shapes reflects the fluid nature of emotions – the way their strength and frequency varies from moment to moment. Select an emotion to learn more.
continents.body_mobile: Most emotions researchers agree on these five Universal Emotions: emotions that all humans, no matter where or how we were raised, have in common. Tap on an emotion to start exploring.

states.body: Here we explore different states and intensities within one emotion family.
states.caption: Least intense, most intense
states.body_mobile: LHAMO can be felt mildly, extremely, or somewhere in between. Tap on the shapes above to learn about a few of the states that we can experience.
states.interaction_prompt: Select a shape to learn about some of the states we can experience.

actions.body: We respond to emotional states with our actions. Our responses to the same emotion may differ depending on the circumstances. We may have a primary, more immediate response, and a secondary more thoughtful response. Any response can be constructive and helpful to ourselves, others and the situation, or destructive and not helpful.
actions.body_mobile: We respond to emotional states with our actions. Tap on the shapes to learn about the possible actions resulting from LHAMO.
actions.interaction_prompt: Select a shape to learn about some of the states we can experience. Then select an action to learn more.

qualities.body: In this state, this action is CONSTRUCTIVE. It's a useful response to the emotion.
qualities.body_mobile: We respond to emotional states with our actions. Tap on the shapes to learn about the possible actions resulting from LHAMO.

qualities.body: In this state, this action is AMBIGUOUS. It could either be a useful response to the emotion or it could cause harm.
qualities.body_mobile: In this state, this action is AMBIGUOUS. It could either be a useful response to the emotion or it could cause harm.

qualities.body: In this state, this action is DESTRUCTIVE. It could cause harm.
qualities.body_mobile: In this state, this action is DESTRUCTIVE. It could cause harm.

triggers.body: A trigger is something around us or in our own minds that causes us to feel an emotion. Select the labels to learn about triggering LHAMO.
triggers.body_mobile: A trigger is something around us or in our own minds that causes us to feel an emotion. Tap on the labels to learn about triggering LHAMO.

steps.body: Some triggers are hardwired and universal for everyone, other triggers are learned from the world around us and our individual experience.
steps.body_mobile: A trigger is something around us or in our own minds that causes us to feel an emotion. Tap on the labels to learn about triggering LHAMO.

steps.body: Past personal experience determines whether or not a learned trigger makes us feel emotional. Universal triggers break through regardless.
steps.body_mobile: Past personal experience determines whether or not a learned trigger makes us feel emotional. Universal triggers break through regardless.

steps.body: Emotion is our automatic response to being triggered. The state of emotion we feel and the actions we take often happen without our realizing why.
steps.body_mobile: Emotion is our automatic response to being triggered. The state of emotion we feel and the actions we take often happen without our realizing why.

steps.body: This is an example of a universal trigger. Everyone has the same universal triggers – we're born with them. They affect us more intensely than learned triggers.
steps.body_mobile: This is an example of a universal trigger. Everyone has the same universal triggers – we're born with them. They affect us more intensely than learned triggers.

steps.body: This is an example of a learned trigger. Some learned triggers are shared across a culture, while others are highly personal and created by individual experiences.
steps.body_mobile: This is an example of a learned trigger. Some learned triggers are shared across a culture, while others are highly personal and created by individual experiences.

moods.body: Moods are longer-lasting cousins of an emotion that cause us to feel the related emotion repeatedly without any clear trigger. Select the shape to learn more.
moods.body_mobile: Moods are longer-lasting cousins of an emotion that cause us to feel the related emotion repeatedly without any clear trigger. Tap on the shape to learn more.

calm.body: The Atlas of Emotion was commissioned by the Dalai Lama, his purpose is "In order to find the new world we needed a map, and in order for us to find a calm mind we need a map of our emotions". The simple, but not easy, goal of this Atlas is to help us be aware of our emotions. Awareness of our emotions means understanding how they are triggered, what they feel like and how we respond. Awareness itself is a strategy, it helps us understand our emotion experiences. We do not want to get rid of our emotions, we want strategies that help us respond in helpful, constructive ways.
calm.caption: Start over
calm.body_mobile: The Atlas of Emotion was commissioned by the Dalai Lama, his purpose is " In order to find the new world we needed a map, and in order for us to find a calm mind we need a map of our emotions". The simple, but not easy, goal of this Atlas is to help us be aware of our emotions. Awareness of our emotions means understanding how they are triggered, what they feel like and how we respond. Awareness itself is a strategy, it helps us understand our emotion experiences. We do not want to get rid of our emotions, we want strategies that help us respond in helpful, constructive ways.

secondary.body: To learn more about emotions, click on "More Information" in the bottom right corner.
secondary.body_mobile: The Atlas of Emotion was commissioned by the Dalai Lama, his purpose is " In order to find the new world we needed a map, and in order for us to find a calm mind we need a map of our emotions". The simple, but not easy, goal of this Atlas is to help us be aware of our emotions. Awareness of our emotions means understanding how they are triggered, what they feel like and how we respond. Awareness itself is a strategy, it helps us understand our emotion experiences. We do not want to get rid of our emotions, we want strategies that help us respond in helpful, constructive ways.

calm.crowdfunding: We are making an atlas for children! If you would like to support this project, please visit our page on .

body: Our emotions unfold on a timeline. The timeline begins with a trigger that initiates an emotional experience and ultimately results in a response.
Try choosing different emotions from the list below the timeline.
Notice how the same trigger can lead to a different response, depending on the emotion we feel.
body_mobile: Our emotions unfold on a timeline. The timeline begins with a trigger that initiates an emotional experience and ultimately results in a response.
Try choosing different emotions from the list below the timeline.
Notice how the same trigger can lead to a different response, depending on the emotion we feel.

body: The trigger occurs in a context:
Our worldview, which is influenced by our prior experiences, personal history and inherited universal scripts about important events
body_mobile: The trigger occurs in a context:
Our worldview, which is influenced by our prior experiences, personal history and inherited universal scripts about important events

body: The emotional experience that is triggered includes subjective feelings and physical sensations. These color our perception of a situation.
body_mobile: The emotional experience that is triggered includes subjective feelings and physical sensations. These color our perception of a situation.

body: We have a choice in how we respond, although sometimes it's hard to feel in control of our responses. Some responses are more constructive than others.
response.button: Why is it hard to stay aware?
body_mobile: We have a choice in how we respond, although sometimes it's hard to feel in control of our responses. Some responses are more constructive than others.

body: When an emotion is triggered we are in the grip of that emotion, which limits our ability to think clearly and choose how we respond.
As time passes, we gain some clarity and the ability to make a thoughtful choice.
With awareness we can pause before we respond and choose a response that best serves our goals.
body_mobile: When an emotion is triggered we are in the grip of that emotion, which limits our ability to think clearly and choose how we respond.
As time passes, we gain some clarity and the ability to make a thoughtful choice.
With awareness we can pause before we respond and choose a response that best serves our goals.

body: You can select each piece of the timeline and learn how researchers make sense of an emotional episode. Then, continue to the Experience section to see how they map our emotional experiences.

captions.precondition: The context, which influences the way we experience the emotion
captions.event: An event that happens in the world or in our own mind
captions.perceptual_database: How we see the world, which is a result of our personal history and universal scripts; these scripts are outlines of repeated emotional experiences, some inherited, some acquired.
captions.physical_changes: The automatic bodily sensations of our emotion
captions.emotional_state: Our combined physical and mental changes
captions.mental_changes: The immediate felt experience of our emotion
captions.constructive_response: A response that helps you in your goals
captions.destructive_response: A response that gets in the way of your goals
captions.ambiguous_response: A response that could be helpful or unhelpful — sometimes we aren't sure

body_mobile: You can select each piece of the timeline and learn how researchers make sense of an emotional episode. Then, continue to the Experience section to see how they map our emotional experiences.
